Environment - policy, planning and administration
To promote inter-sector approaches to BD conservation through the tourism and fisheries sectors
Area of mangroves throughout the coastal/marine zone

comment.narrative: Baseline Level was updated (Source: 2010 Map of Ecosystems of El Salvador, MARN-PACAP) Jiquilisco Bay 21,191.12 ha Jaltepeque 7,162.00 ha Barra de Santiago (Garita Palmera, Bola de Monte) 2,497.00 ha Costa del BÃ¡lsamo (San Diego, Toluca) 393 ha Golfo de Fonseca (Cerique, El Tamarindo and La UniÃ³n) 8,979.00 ha Los CÃ³banos (Barra Salada, other river mouths) 495 ha TOTAL 40717.12 ha (2010)

Target Level was updated based on the Baseline Level (Source: 2010 Map of Ecosystems of El Salvador, MARN-PACAP) Jiquilisco Bay 21,191.12 ha Jaltepeque 7,162.00 ha Barra de Santiago (Garita Palmera, Bola de Monte) 2,497.00 ha Costa del BÃ¡lsamo (San Diego, Toluca) 393 ha Golfo de Fonseca (Cerique, El Tamarindo and La UniÃ³n) 8,979.00 ha Los CÃ³banos (Barra Salada, other river mouths) 495 ha TOTAL 40717.12 ha (2010)

The project has been able to conserve the target mangrove areas (21,191.12 ha) as a result of the joint efforts of the several governmental institutions MARN, PNC, CENDEPESCA, local governments and communities. The recent published "Fifth Biodiversity National Report" list the following: Jiquilisco Bay: 21191.12 hectares, Jaltepeque: 7162.00 hectares, Barra de Santiago: 2497.00 hectares, Costa del Balsamo: 393 ha, Gulf of Fonseca: 8979.00 hectares, Los Cóbanos: 495 ha. Mangrove areas in El Salvador have been maintained, achieving the Project’s goal, as a joint effort between the institutions and the general population.
The environmental zoning document was formulated within the Project, and it has been and promoted to all coastal municipalities on June 2, 2015, by MARN. The municipal governments are supporting the efforts for the conservation of the mangrove and other resources through the creation of 7 municipal regulations (Acajutla, Intipuca,Conchagua, San Dionisio, San Alejo, Jiquilisco, Meanguera del Golfo) which creates a better protection of the natural resources. MARN continues with the declaration of new protective áreas, late december 2014 the área Bara de Santiago was declared as Humedal Ramsar with an extension of 11,519 hectares, making it a new tool for the ecosystem’s management

description.narrative: Number of turtle nests throughout the coastal/marine zone

comment.narrative: Lepidochelys olivacea 6,409 Chenia mydas agassizii 1,279 Dermochelys coriacea 23 Eretmochelys imbricata 80 TOTAL 7,791 (2008)
Lepidochelys olivacea 6,409 Chenia mydas agassizii 1,279 Dermochelys coriacea 23 Eretmochelys imbricata 80 TOTAL 7,791 (2014)

During the reported period a total of 11,723 sea turtle nests have been tracked in the 2014-2015 season and distributed as follow:
Lepidochelys olivacea 11,479; Chenia mydas agassizii 48; Dermochelys coriacea 18; Eretmochelys imbricata 181.Turtle nesting varies from one year to another, however, due to the constant monitoring of MARN and the support of the PNC, the proposed goal of the Project during this period has been surpassed. MARN supports the different efforts for the conservation of the marine turtle in the whole coastal area of El Salvador, among other actions it executes the “ Action plan for the conservation of marine turtles in El Salvador 2010-2020” which seeks to provide guidelines and operative work liniments for the sustainable managing of the marine turtles nationwide; prioritize the conservation actions according to the opportunities and the dilemmas and define the mechanisms for the implementation of the same plan. CENDEPESCA presented the country’s report about following the excluding devices of marine turtles (TED’s) device that allows the sea turtle to escape the net used to catch shrimps. Achieving more than 70% of inspections done

description.narrative: Area of live coral populations in Los CÃ³banos Conservation Area

comment.narrative: Porites lobata 0.1 km2 Psammcora obtusangula 100 m2 Psammcora stellata 1m2
Porites lobata 0.1km2 Psammcora obtusangula 100m2 Psammcora stellata 1m2

CENDEPESCA and MARN have worked all year in the preservation and conservation of the reef popolation in Los Cobanos, and have involved the participation of the local communities and local government. The Project has been updating Los Cobanos Management Plan and is in the process of completing the RAMSAR´s file to be presented at the end of August 2015. The project has been supportive to MARN’s management of wetlands, with provision of specialized team for the monitoring of coral reefs that allows a greater and precise measurement of the coral reef’s areas. Resulting in an increase in relationship to the areas reported during the rise of the base line.

description.narrative: Available shrimp biomass

comment.narrative: 266 metric tons (year 2005)
1,000 metric tons

The project is in the final stage of preparing the 2015 biomass study, that will be finished in November. MARN in coordination with CENDEPESCA has developed different efforts heading to the protection of shrimp and other species reproduction areas, where we can mention the reduction of fishing through pumping mainly at the Bahia de Jiquilisco and greater control to avoid the fishing through net dragging in the three marine miles by industrial ships. Establishment of vans for shrimp catch which develops each year

description.narrative: Policies and regulations of the tourism and fisheries sectors support forms of production that are compatible with resource sustainability and biodiversity conservation
Existence of National Policy for Sustainable Tourism, incorporating provisions for biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Overall Tourism Development Plan exists
National policy and plan exist for the promotion and development of sustainable tourism, incorporating provisions for biodiversity conservation

MITUR-CORSATUR is applying the National Tourism Policy on a daily basis activities and it is one of the main strategic tool to guide at a national and local level to approach sustainalbe tourism development. A National Gobernance Sustainable Tourism Plan for the coastal zone was launched and it will be the base for present and future tourism programs and projects, the Ministers have announced the importance of having this new plan. In addition, Educational tourism guides have prepared as another result.

description.narrative: Existence of a Sustainable Fisheries Policy

comment.narrative: National Fisheries Policy exists but does not make explicit provision for considerations of biodiversity conservation and sustainability
Sustainable Fisheries Policy developed jointly by CENDEPESCA and MARN, and under implementation

It is plan to launch in september 2015 the Sustainalbe fisheries policy, which CENDEPESCA in coordination with MARN have been puting together during an intensive consultancy process, where different sectors related to this activity have been participating and the incorporation of biodiversity conservation and sustainability of fishery resource have been a main focal approach.

description.narrative: Number of active members of Sustainable Tourism Network (STN)

comment.narrative: Sustainable Tourism Network does not exist

Active members of STN include:
- MITUR
- CORSATUR
- Representatives of private sector tourism operators
- Muicipal governments

A second course on Biodiversity and Sustainable Tourism and adaptation to climate change is given to an additional group of 30 tour operators, to strength their abilities in planning and implementing sustainable tourism.

description.narrative: Number of municipalities throughout the coastal/marine zone actively collaborating with central Government institutions in planning and promoting BD-friendly tourism and fisheries.

comment.narrative: 18 municipalities of the coastal zone have worked together with government and other organizations putting together several results and creating an impact on sustainable tourism and conservation of biodiversity: a study on estuary and marine fishery has been done, 8 legal instruments on environment and biodiversity protection are done in the same number of municipalities, two municipalities are members of rural community tourism bureau, environmental education processes is taking place and it is coordianted with MARN, support to women in the marketing of seafood is underway, projects on conservation of sea turtles are underway and supported by 4 municipalities. MARN has submitted the zoning study generated through the BPT project to each of the coastal municipalities.This has allowed them better understanding of the effects caused by extreme events, such as the heavy sea in May this year, thus becoming a management tool

description.narrative: Level of advance with the development of norms for sustainable production in the fisheries and tourism sectors

comment.narrative: The General Law for the Ordering and Promotion of Fisheries and Aquaculture has been implemented but there are significant weaknesses in terms of monitoring and control in its application
The General Law for the Ordering and Promotion of Fisheries and Aquaculture and its regulation have been updated, including norms for sustainable fisheries.

Draft of the General Law for the Management and Promotion of Fisheries and Aquaculture still under revision to be summited this year for approval.
Seven municipalities have prepared local legal instruments related to biosiversity conservation.

description.narrative: Number of key institutions with functioning systems for monitoring the condition of natural resources

comment.narrative: MARN
MARN MITUR CENDEPESCA CONAPESCA

Four institutions (MARN, CENDEPESCA, National Civil Police, and MITUR-CORSATUR) have developed functional systems for monitoring the state of natural resources: training and GPS application, equipment for data processing of fisheries is under implementation; 2 new vessels for monitoring and biodiversity conservation have been provided. Monitoring capacities of MARN have been strengthened through a national radio system for the location of industrial vessels (1,500 km²), as part of strengthening of the Environmental Observatory, in coordination with CENDEPESCA. MARN’s MARN´s Wetlandhas taken place by updating the fisheries statistical system (diagnosis of the current statistical system and proposal of improvements; fingering of 35,000 field ballots with information on fishing disembarkments in order to feed the database).

description.narrative: Number of institutions with specific strategic guidelines in their strategic plans for the conservation and regeneration of natural resources

comment.narrative: 3 MARN MITUR CENDEPESCA

MITUR- CORSATUR is implementing the National Tourism Policy and has officially launched the National Gobernance and Sustainable Tourism Plan for the Coastal zone. CENDEPESCA has a fishing policy, which includes the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainability of the fishery resource and a Draft of the General Law for the Management and Promotion of Fisheries and Aquaculture is underway.Seven municipalities have prepared legal instruments on biodiversity protection.

description.narrative: Producers have the capacities and motivation to operate in accordance with principles of resource sustainability and biodiversity conservation
Average size of molluscs and crustaceans caught in Los CÃ³banos

comment.narrative: Strombus galeatu 20.65 ± 4.56 cm Striostrea prismatica (Ostrea iridescens) 12.5 cm Panulirus gracilis 6.2 ± 9.3 (hembras) cm
Strombus galeatus 25 cm Striostrea prismatica (Ostrea iridescens) 15 cm Panulirus gracilis 7.0 cm
A study is underway with special emphasis on these species and it will be ready by november 2015.

description.narrative: Average size of shark (S. lewini) individuals caught

comment.narrative: 50cm
100cm

Currently the project is finishing an update study on sharks information and also it will provide information of the impact obtained by the government ban´s that takes place each year. According to a 2012 shark report done by Cendepesca, the average size of capture species is 51.73 cm. However, CENDEPESCA established a ban during the breeding period, avoiding the capture of individuals under 150 cm for one month in 2014 and 2015.

description.narrative: Number of fishers selling directly to consumers in main urban markets

comment.narrative: 46 members of El Cuco ADESCO
144 organized fishers in CÃ³banos, sell directly to consumers (e.g. tourists, the general public, restaurants and businesses)

171 organized fishermen in cooperatives are commercializing their products directly to final client (individuals, markets, restaurants, etc): 23 fishermen from Cooperative Tiburoneros of the High Seas of Acajutla.
34 from Cooperative Los Cóbanos, 36 from Cooperative ACOPACIFICO.
47 from Cooperative ASPESCU, and
31 from Cooperative ACOPPSEMPET.

description.narrative: Number of fishers adopting BD-friendly standards throughout the coastal/marine zone

comment.narrative: 325 (2.5% of the total)
650 (5% of the total)

653 fishermen continue implementing friendly fishing practices with biodiversity, using methods and fishing gear permitted by the competent authority, such as handline, longline , gillnet or permitted fishing areas.These fishermen have been receiving advice and supports to use 4” fisher net , whereby the catch of juveniles decreases.Investigations are under development to assess the productivity of artificial reefs.

description.narrative: Number of artisan fishers that are members of fisheries cooperatives

comment.narrative: Ministry of Agriculture has reported 180 fisheries cooperatives with 4,424 members

description.narrative: Unit prices received by fishers in Los CÃ³banos participating in schemes for direct marketing of produce to consumers in main urban markets

comment.narrative:
Shark: $1.00/lb Paid to fishers
$3.20/lb Paid by consumers Shrimp: $2.25/lb Paid to fishers
$5.89/lb Paid by consumer

Shark: $1.90/lb Paid to fishers
$3.00/lb Paid by consumer Shrimp: $3.68/lb Paid to fishers
$5.50/lb Paid by consumer
Fisheries Cooperatives report: Shark: $ 1.35 paid to producers and $ 2.25 paid to the intermediary; and Shrimp $8.50paid to the producer, and $12.00paid to the intermediary.

description.narrative: Proportional contribution of nature-based tourism to tourism sector revenues

comment.narrative: MITUR-CORSATUR information, at least 30% of tourist operators are implementing environment and biodiversity friendly activities. With the new Sustainable Tourism Policy and the National Plan for Governance and Management of Sustainable Tourism in the coastal-marine area of El Salvador, more tourism operators will increase sustainable practices.

description.narrative: National and local institutions are able effectively to support the mainstreaming of biodiversity considerations into management of the coastal/marine zone
Number of municipalities with staff designated to supporting and regulating production activities in line with BD considerations.

comment.narrative: 18hav

18 municipalities continue with assigned staff who is responsible to apply biodiversity protection and environment approach and to apply the different legal framework, mechanism and instruments like the environmental zoning of the coastal-marine area and are members of sustainable tourism network. Also 32 municipalities have surveillance system with the National Civil Police’s support.

description.narrative: Number of tourism operations (hotels and restaurants) subjected to annual inspection of BD impacts and mitigation measures (by central and municipal Government, sector self-regulation entities or certification bodies)

comment.narrative: 25% of registered businesses in 18 coastal municipalities

A reporting system has been designed, which will increase the companies with annual inspections in 15%.Indicators on status and conservation of biodiversity are being included in the evaluation instruments of MARN and MITUR/CORSATUR (RNT).

description.narrative: Area of the coastal/marine zone covered by zoning and sustainable development plans for tourism and fisheries

comment.narrative: 145km2 of aquatic reserves (5 reserves) 213km2 of special management regimes (Los CÃ³banos and Gulf of Fonseca) Zoning and sustainable development plans exist in Jiquilisco Bay and (in process) Los CÃ³banos
1,500 km2 (3 miles seaward and same inland)

The document with guidelines for decision-making in 1,500 km2 of the coastal marine strip has been reported and put it into practice.Indicators on status and conservation of biodiversity are being included in the evaluation instruments of MARN and MITUR/CORSATUR. There are also guidelines for environmental zoning in Los Cóbanos, and the eastern part of the coastal marine strip; and action guidelines for the orderly use of resources scale 1:25, 00; and environmental zoning of the territorial units of high and extreme environmental sensitivity scale 1: 5,000, and their respective performance guidelines.

description.narrative: Amount of funds channelled to monitoring, control and promotion of BD-friendly activities from private sector corporate responsibility programmes and municipal fiscal mechanisms

comment.narrative: To be determined at project startup
To be determined at project startup

$951,932.03 in funds channeled to the supervision, control and promotion of environmentally friendly activities with the BD, from corporate responsibility programs of private companies to municipal fiscal mechanisms.
